meanings.def: if something bounces or you bounce it, it moves quickly away from a surface it has just hit or you make it do this
examples: The ball bounced twice before he could reach it.
bounce off something Short sound waves bounce off even small objects.
The light bounced off the river and dazzled her.
+ adv./prep. The ball bounced high and she missed it.
bounce something (against/on/off something) She bounced the ball against the wall.
The stone hit the window but bounced off.
(figurative) The idea had been bouncing around in my head for some time.

meanings.def: to jump up and down on something
examples: She bounced up and down excitedly on the bed.

meanings.def: to move a child up and down while they are sitting on your knee in order to entertain them
examples: I bounced the baby on my knee while Pete did the dishes.

meanings.def: to move up and down; to move something up and down
examples: Her hair bounced as she walked.

meanings.def: to move up and down in a particular direction
examples: The bus bounced down the hill.
The car bounced its way along the dirt road.

meanings.def: to move somewhere in a lively and cheerful way
examples: He bounced across the room to greet them.

meanings.def: if a cheque bounces, or a bank bounces it, the bank refuses to accept it because there is not enough money in the bank account to pay it
to tell somebody your ideas in order to find out what they think about them
examples: He bounced ideas off colleagues everywhere he went.

meanings.def: if an email bounces or the system bounces it, it returns to the person who sent it because the system cannot deliver it
examples: I tried to send her an email but it bounced.
The system automatically bounces emails which contain attachments.

meanings.def: to force somebody to leave a job, team, place, etc.
examples: He was soon bounced from the post.

meanings.def: to leave a place or group of people
examples: All right, cool, we'll bounce.

meanings.def: to be so full of energy or so excited that you cannot keep still
examples: The kids have been bouncing off the walls all day.

idioms.def: to be so full of energy or so excited that you cannot keep still
examples: The kids have been bouncing off the walls all day.
one bounce of the ball
(North American English) a bounce (= increase) in popularity

meanings.def: the ability to bounce or to make something bounce
examples: There's not much bounce left in these balls.
Players complained about the uneven bounce of the tennis court.

meanings.def: the energy that a person has
examples: All her old bounce was back.
There was a bounce to his step.

meanings.def: the quality in a person’s hair that shows that it is in good condition and means that it does not lie flat
examples: thin fine hair, lacking in bounce

meanings.def: one after the other, without anything else coming between
examples: We've won six matches on the bounce.

idioms.def: one after the other, without anything else coming between
examples: We've won six matches on the bounce.
